The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. It also provides a model for the use of DNA metabarcoding to study diet composition in other systems.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes and transcriptomes to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, the evolution of genes enabling lignocellulose digestion, and the diversification of beetles and their plant-feeding lineages.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the APOE ε4 allele, which increases AD risk by ∼12-fold. APOE is a protein that is involved in many biological processes, but its role in AD is not yet clear. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This study provides a better understanding of the role of APOE in AD and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The inner core is the densest part of the Earth, and its structure and dynamics are important for understanding the dynamics of the entire planet. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we propose a new mechanism of the inner core formation, which is based on the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics. Our study also provides a new perspective for understanding the structure and dynamics of the inner core. This work will contribute to our understanding of the Earth and the universe. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is widely used, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use leads to reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). The reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use in the human brain.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also capture the majority of neural activity in the human brain during language comprehension and predict how people solve a challenging language task. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is often unstable. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that the algorithms used to train DL models are unstable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can solve inverse problems with high accuracy. This is a major advance in the field, and it will allow us to use DL models in applications that were previously impossible.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

The dynamics of quantum systems is a central theme in physics. In this work, we study the dynamics of entanglement, which is a key resource in quantum information science. We show that the dynamics of entanglement is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is a major step toward understanding the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems.

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, was one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. The disease led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with arguments for both rats and fleas. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances its ability to sever the filaments. This mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell junctions. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF can regulate the mechanical properties of the actin cytoskeleton. This mechanism may be relevant to a variety of processes, including cell migration and cell division.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related metabolic diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries, with a recent demographic history. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of Madagascar and the rest of the Indian Ocean. This work also suggests that people are more likely to experience positive emotions when they are around others who are also positive, and that people are more likely to experience negative emotions when they are around others who are also negative. These results have implications for the design of social networks, and for the way that people use social networks.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are also evident over a 4-y period. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships. This may be particularly important in older age, when the sense of purpose and meaningfulness in life may be particularly important for maintaining health and well-being.

The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the temperature of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major human pathogen that causes a variety of diseases, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis. This opportunistic pathogen is notorious for its ability to rapidly adapt to its environment, including the surfaces of solid objects, and to cause disease in immunocompromised individuals. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the pili, which in turn regulates the pili and the production of virulence factors. This study provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence, and may lead to the development of new strategies for the control of this pathogen.

Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, and the discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The disease is believed to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are deposited in the brain and trigger a sustained microglial response. Our findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. They also suggest that the early stages of the disease may be characterized by a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may be a target for future treatments.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, in which a system adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of molecular exchange. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after copulation, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the protein to a second state with faster binding, which is important for platelet binding. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, and it is likely to be important in other systems.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface is a key factor in the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is a matter of great debate. Here, we use the thermostability of enzymes to infer the temperature of the surface of the early Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. Ion channels are composed of a protein core and a pore gate. The pore gate is responsible for the opening and closing of the channel pore. Ion channels are classified into three types based on the number of pore gates. This study focuses on the K+ channel BK, which has two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of the disease. Here, we show that the parasite uses a number of physical mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including changes in the shape of the red blood cell, changes in the cytoskeleton, and changes in the membrane. These changes in the red blood cell are likely to be important in facilitating invasion. This work suggests that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in electronics, photonics, and quantum devices. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. This work shows that diamond can be transformed into a metal, which is ductile and can be shaped into any desired form. This work is expected to be useful for applications of diamond in electronics, photonics, and quantum devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza. The brain is thought to build a representation of the syntactic structure of a sentence word by word, but whether and how this is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain builds a representation of the syntactic structure of a sentence word by word, but whether and how this is implemented in the brain remains unknown.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development, cell fate, and cell proliferation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin. This is a unique feature that may be common in other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.
This study provides a comprehensive characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is a key limiting resource for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a major goal of synthetic biology. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in which the nitrogenase enzyme, which fixes atmospheric nitrogen, is controlled by a plant signal. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to engineer other nitrogen-cycling organisms, such as cyanobacteria, and could be applied to other systems, such as the nitrogen cycle in the ocean.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause suffering and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. Here we report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a recombinant protein that can be used to manufacture a vaccine. The protein is derived from the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. The protein is highly immunogenic and can be used to manufacture a vaccine.

We report on the discovery of a new class of ligands for the ALK/LTK receptor family. We show that the zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. We further show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest a role for ALKALs in the development of other tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence is responsible for some of the most devastating outbreaks. The history of plague is poorly understood because of the difficulty in recovering ancient DNA. Here, we present the genomes of 17 ancient plague strains, which provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its rapid spread across Eurasia.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, a candidate who was widely perceived as a threat to gender, racial, and class hierarchies. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of HM.

The management of agricultural systems has a profound impact on the amount and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the soil. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols can be optimized to increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools. This is important because the distribution of SOC between these two pools is a key determinant of SOC stability. The results of this study highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial pastures into annual cropping systems to increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the effects of management on soil processes. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and use them to inform research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for systematically identifying and prioritizing zoonotic threats and can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms by which this trait is evolved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment and demonstrate that the same three enzymatic activities are responsible for the production of the red color in a distantly related hummingbird-visited species. This work provides evidence for convergent evolution of a key trait in two different vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a model for the study of the evolution of nectar color in plants.

The history of Europe is marked by complex demographic processes, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the Germanic peoples and the arrival of the Vikings is largely unknown. Here we present genome-wide data from a group of women who lived in southern Germany at the end of the 5th century AD. Our data indicate that they were of mixed ancestry, including genetic signals from western Europe, eastern Europe, and East Asia. In addition, we show that they differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells. These findings provide insights into the molecular basis of MERS-CoV pathogenesis and the transmission of bat coronaviruses to humans. They also suggest that the use of DPP4

This study demonstrates the feasibility of using a global cloud-based platform for pathogen surveillance in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in Cambodia. This study also highlights the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens, and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also demonstrates the potential of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, where the cost of laboratory infrastructure is prohibitive. This study is a step toward the development of a global mNGS platform for pathogen surveillance. This platform can be used to identify the pathogen landscape in resource-scarce settings, and to deploy rapid public health response. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from the PCNA sliding clamp on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the implications of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. This knowledge will be useful in understanding the replication process and the role of pol δ in human diseases.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this study, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step forward in the quest to understand the origins of life, because it allows the study of the replication of RNA, a process that is essential for the evolution of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage, and the clinical outcomes are still unsatisfactory. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, can improve the clinical outcomes of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is poorly understood. Here we report the existence of a copper-binding natural product in Aspergillus fumigatus, a fungus that is a leading cause of invasive fungal disease. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungi in the environment and human health, and for the development of antifungal strategies.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature SiO2 polymorph, in a sedimentary environment is unusual. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at the base of a crater wall/rim/central peak suggests that the peak was formed by a volcanic event.

Frost events are a major source of crop and animal losses, but the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the evolutionary history of the species, and that this history is likely to have shaped the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings can be used to inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of colitis by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. We report a method to rapidly convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which can be used to model the disease in vitro. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of new therapies.

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors is an emerging area of research. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum alters the gut microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for the pathogen. These data provide a molecular framework for the role of the microbiota in vector-borne disease transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in the history of vertebrates. The study of the origins of the short-tailed bird group is critical for understanding the evolution of the modern avian body plan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, which adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.
We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to understand the role of the stratosphere in climate.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate is determined by the absorption of light by pigments in the skin, such as carotenoids, and by the color of the bones, which are often green. In this study, we describe a new mechanism for the green color of vertebrates, which is based on the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the reduced form of the protein chlorophyll. This discovery has implications for the evolution of vertebrates and for the study of the biology of the green color.

This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the metastatic potential of the tumor. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. This study shows that the source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” was not fetal calves or sheep, as has been assumed, but rather the skins of maturing animals of several species.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a critical control on the timing of the onset of global environmental perturbation, the magnitude of the carbon cycle disruption, and the timing of recovery. The age model for the extinction is based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age model, based on a single datum, is precise and precise, but the age of the extinction is highly uncertain.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unknown. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. We generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune response in infected individuals. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in the closed and open conformations. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein leads to a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This may explain the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. Our data provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings highlight the need for public health interventions to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to and mortality from COVID-19 and other infectious diseases.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the study of chemical phenomena. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is a general trend for most elements. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of compounds under pressure. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant drivers of changes in fire activity over the past century. However, climate change has also played a role, and we show that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks may be able to offset some of the warming caused by human ignitions. This suggests that climate change may be less damaging to the global carbon cycle in the future than previously thought. However, climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective under lower emission scenarios, and the risk of more extreme fires is not negligible.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the symbiosis between a host and its associated microbes. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the production of bioluminescence at night. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is quiescent, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the host is active. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the symbiosis between a host and its associated microbes. It also suggests that the provision of glycans by the host to its symbionts may be a general strategy used by hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study may also have implications for the study of other symbioses, such as those between plants and their associated microbes. (Read more)

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in machine learning and word embedding to model topics in text. Our method, discourse atom topic modeling, is able to identify latent topics in text data, and to represent documents as topic sequences. We apply our method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. This work is a step toward the goal of understanding the world from the perspective of text.

The second plague pandemic, which began in the 14th century, was the consequence of multiple introductions of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague. We show that the first introduction of plague into Europe was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium, which took place over a period of 40 y. We also show that the first introduction of plague into Europe was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium, which took place over a period of 40 y.
This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars. The study also provides a mechanism for the spread of the virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor, which is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used to develop more efficient and effective therapies for AML. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries, with a recent demographic history. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of Madagascar and the rest of the Indian Ocean. This information will be useful for the conservation of the biodiversity and the cultural diversity of the region. Bacteria are able to sense and respond to a wide variety of environmental cues. One of the most important cues is the availability of carbon sources. In this study, we describe a small RNA that regulates the carbon utilization of Escherichia coli.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing information on crop status and conditions that are critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information provided by crop experts is often difficult to use for quantitative analysis because of its subjective nature. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information for the US Department of Agriculture, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the CPC is robust and stable over time, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the management of agricultural production and the development of large-scale monitoring systems.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this function in the brain. Information is stored in the dynamics of the membrane potential, which is itself modulated by synaptic and intrinsic plasticity. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major source of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the atmosphere, and its response to climate change is of great importance for our understanding of the global carbon cycle. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in the study of the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the evolutionary rate of the plastid genome is a function of the degree of functional reduction, which in turn is a function of the lifestyle of the host.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is likely to be even larger in other regions of the world. The results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known example of a quasicrystal, found in a meteorite, is now over 40 years old. Here, we report the discovery of a second example of a quasicrystal, this time in a sample of the “Trinity” test debris from the first nuclear explosion.

Photosynthesis is the process by which plants, algae, and cyanobacteria convert solar energy into chemical energy. The conversion of solar energy into chemical energy is achieved by the capture of light by pigments, the conversion of the energy of the absorbed photons into chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The latter two molecules are used in the synthesis of organic molecules, such as starch and sugars, which are used for the growth and development of the organism.

Neuroinflammation is a key feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a major role in microglia-mediated neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in later-stage neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of MS. It also provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of MS. (PsycINFO Database Record
The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 can lead to severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1, which can be used to understand the molecular basis of these conditions and to develop new therapies.

The study of the spreading of protein aggregates in the brain is a key area of research in neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain is a complex process that involves both active release and internalization of aggregates. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the control of viral infections. This study may also provide a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the control of viral infections. Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and thus requires the maintenance of one-carbon units. We report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1 (SHMT1) and 2 (SHMT2), which are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also report the discovery of a second series of small-molecule SHMT inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo, but are more effective in cancer cell lines that are deficient in glycine import. This latter class of SHMT inhibitor is a promising lead for the treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is resistant to standard therapies. Thus, the discovery of these two classes of SHMT inhibitors provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but prone to aggregation in ALS. This metastable state is likely a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and may be a target for therapeutic intervention. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The device is designed to produce exotic quantum phenomena, such as suppressed spontaneous decay, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal, and emission of light in a direction that is not parallel to the direction of propagation of the light. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have broad impact in many-body physics, quantum optics, and atomic physics.

The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, is of great importance for understanding the evolution of the angiosperms. The study of Montsechia has been difficult because of the poor quality of the original material and the lack of knowledge of its age and place of origin. The study presented here provides a detailed description of the plant, including its anatomy and reproduction. The study also provides a detailed analysis of the age of the plant and its place of origin.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is important to understand the evolutionary history of the viruses that infect humans. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been associated with humans for a long time.
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem, and the elderly are more likely to report pain than those in midlife. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain prevalence has increased for each successive birth cohort of the less educated, but not for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase seen across birth cohorts cannot be explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity for the less educated, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate in a pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzyme with the natural substrate indole. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into both structure and dynamics, and the importance of the chemical environment in enzyme catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment in MERS-CoV infection.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the symbiosis between a host and its associated microbes. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the production of bioluminescence by the host organ. This glycan is provided only at night, when the host is active and the symbiont is dormant, and its catabolism is required for the host to acidify the crypts, which enhances the symbiont’s capacity to produce bioluminescence. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the symbiosis between a host and its associated microbes. It also suggests that the provision of glycans by the host to its symbionts may be a general strategy used by hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study may also have implications for the study of other symbioses, such as those between fungi and plants and between bacteria and other animals. (Read more)

This research is about the importance of relationships in schools. It shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a major impact on students’ behavior and well-being. It also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline through a scalable intervention.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylated DNA lesions on transcription. We found that the presence of alkylated DNA lesions can lead to transcriptional stalling, which is dependent on the proofreading activity of RNA polymerase II. Furthermore, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, which is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work also provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of mutagenesis induced by alkylation. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new strategies for cancer therapy.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors, and then fuse with the cell membrane. Here, we show that sequential cleavage of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins is required for virus binding and for fusion, and that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV tropism.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the environment and on population health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 78.8%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that the proportion of vegetarian meals could be increased further without a significant impact on overall sales. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way to improve population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. Here we provide a systems-level view of how specific oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to a broad audience, including cancer biologists, cell biologists, and proteomics researchers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for the expansion of vote-by-mail programs in the United States. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the causal effect of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that may be useful in the future to safeguard the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of infections and thousands of deaths. The virus has a large number of proteins that are not found in other coronaviruses, and the function of many of these proteins is unknown. Here, we report the structure of one of these proteins, ORF8, which is involved in immune evasion.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with increased expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4), endothelin-1 (ET-1), and corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion, hypoxic cerebral edema is mediated by CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. This study provides a molecular mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. It may also be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to be misled by associations that are just noise. This paper describes a way of assessing the importance of associations that is appropriate for the era of big data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we report the discovery of ETV2, a transcription factor that is essential for the development of ECs. We demonstrate that ETV2 is a key factor for the development of ECs in both vitro and in vivo. Our study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the construction of vascular networks. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be a useful tool for the development of new strategies for the treatment of vascular disorders.

We report the discovery of a new class of ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We also report the discovery of a new role for these ligands in the development of the zebrafish pigment system.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder, which is characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin resistance has been extensively studied, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Here, we found that STING plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin secretion, which is impaired in STING-deficient β-cells. These data suggest that STING is required for β-cell function and establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the development of novel therapeutic strategies for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The genetic diversity of the viral genome is limited, and the genome is divided into eight segments, which are packaged into the virion. The packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, and the molecular details are unknown. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of viral RNA segments that are in close contact with each other. This mechanism is sequence dependent and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of the packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a major cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving multiple factors. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Therefore, our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing wildfire risk and the need for policies to reduce fire risk.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus is cleared from the body within 5 d in 50% of the animals, and that the virus can persist for up to 10 d in others. We also show that the virus can persist in the body for a long time in a small fraction of the animals, and that the time to clearance of the virus from the body can be shortened by an antiviral treatment. These results provide a framework for the design of clinical trials of antiviral drugs and vaccines. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that lead to the loss of corals and their associated biodiversity, and they may help us to understand the stability of other endosymbiotic relationships in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host–microbe interaction. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a dynamic tissue that is constantly responding to internal and external signals. We also show that the intestinal epithelium is a hub of communication between the host and the microbiome.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We show that the expression of a receptor, ROR1, is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This increase in ROR1 expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody, cirmtuzumab, is more effective than treatment with either chemotherapy alone. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation is marked by a rapid advance of the Laurentide and Greenland ice sheets, changes in climate conditions, and a shift in the position of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. We show that the start of deglaciation was linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in climate conditions.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries for food security. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the need to protect rivers from other threats to biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve the management of freshwater fisheries and to include them in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles.
