The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, it suggests that the ability to regenerate after injury is a more general feature of the nervous system than previously thought.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of a species. However, the spatial distribution of recombination across the genome is poorly understood. Here, we describe the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant, which is a key evolutionary model.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the human brain is organized in functionally distinct networks, which are active in different states of consciousness. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results are controversial. Here, we used metabolic PET, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total activity, to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We observed that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance in healthy subjects and early PD patients, but not in advanced PD. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from PD and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present

This paper is about a new type of RNA modification that is found in bacteria and yeast, but not in humans. This modification is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNAs, and is not found on any of the other types of RNAs that are known to be modified in eukaryotes. The authors propose that this modification plays a role in the regulation of gene expression.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persist for several years during the follow-up of the EDIC Study. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the metabolic memory phenomenon.
This study provides a better understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a complex disease, which is characterized by a high rate of relapse. The present study suggests that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence, since it is altered in subjects with this disorder. Moreover, the gut microbiota may be a target for the management of alcohol dependence, since it is involved in the development of gut barrier alterations and in the behavioral symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which contribute to the overall aroma and flavor. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato flavor is unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a pathway for the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical because, in the absence of changes in biodiversity, the impacts of warming on ecosystem functioning are already substantial.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for the formation of spatial representations. However, the organization of its neurons is still poorly understood. Here, we report the results of a large-scale, free-moving, in-depth analysis of the spatial organization of MEC neurons. We show that grid cells, which are thought to be the main neurons involved in the formation of spatial representations, are strongly connected among themselves, but weakly connected to other cell types. These results provide a more complete view of the organization of the spatial map in MEC. They also suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from other cell types. This study provides a framework for future studies of the spatial organization of the brain.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the dodder. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of this disease is unknown, but it is thought to be related to a loss of dopamine-related function. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of neurons in the substantia nigra that is critical to dopamine-related function.

We are all social creatures, and we all seek connection. But how do we know when we are connecting with others? We asked people to talk with each other, and we measured the speed at which they responded to each other. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt to each other. This effect was driven by the speed at which people responded to their partners, not by the speed at which they responded to each other. This suggests that people are using the speed at which they respond to each other as a signal of connection. This signal is used by others to assess the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart, and its function is critical for the normal heart rate and rhythm. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of electrical signals. We report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. Our studies reveal that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the generation of electrical signals in these cells. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that control SAN function and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart disease. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA act in concert to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for pest management. (Show more)

This study provides a new view on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also reveals that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports this function in the brain. Information is stored in the dynamics of the membrane potential, which is itself modulated by synaptic and intrinsic plasticity. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it enables the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task, and the delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNA is even more challenging. Here, we report the delivery of RNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the delivery of RNA to plants. We also show that the delivery of RNA to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

We show that the nutrient inputs to a large lake are dominated by a small number of large tributaries, but that the nutrient loads from smaller tributaries are disproportionately high in dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that small tributaries may be a major source of coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should focus on these smaller watersheds.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to access only a small fraction of the chemical concentrations. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a system of particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a strong tendency to concentrate in states with a fine-tuned extremization of the external potential.

This paper is about the brain, but it is also about the nature of science. It is about the importance of a good theory, and the importance of a good theory to the process of science. It is about the importance of a good theory to the process of discovery. It is about the importance of a good theory to the process of understanding.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history is critical to understanding the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming. Here, we present a study of an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative carbon and uranium isotopic excursions, which can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over a large area and to anoxia of the seafloor. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxia can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study provides insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming and the role of the biosphere in the evolution of the Earth system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification appears to be most effective in reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations that are already degraded and contain little residual forest. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the mechanisms that determine sex are often the focus of intense study. However, the evolutionary consequences of sex determination are often overlooked. Here we show that the evolutionary consequences of sex determination can be highly variable, depending on the number of sex determination alleles segregating in a population.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is also challenged by accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by reactive oxygen species and photodegraded into damaging species. We show that the intracellular level of iron, which is critical for redox reactions, is important for the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla, the structures used for prey capture, is highly specialized to the prey type. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings are relevant to understanding the evolution of predators in general.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the hand in the hominin lineage leading to the evolution of modern humans.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and thus requires the maintenance of one-carbon units. We report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1 (SHMT1) and 2 (SHMT2), which are effective in vitro and in vivo. We also report the discovery of a second series of small-molecule SHMT inhibitors, which are effective in vitro and in vivo, but are more effective in cancer cell lines that are deficient in glycine import. This latter class of SHMT inhibitor is a promising lead for the treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, the discovery of these two classes of SHMT inhibitors is a significant advance in the treatment of cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in terms of vitamin A adequacy. This is a significant finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study has implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The history of modern agriculture is the history of mechanization, with the increase in vehicle weight leading to the compaction of soil, a process that has been shown to have negative effects on soil functioning. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has increased by a factor of 10 since the 1950s, and that the compaction of subsoil, which is the main reservoir of soil organic matter, has now become a widespread problem. We also show that the weight of modern farm machinery is now comparable to that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that the compaction of soil by these prehistoric giants may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. This suggests that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This may have been a key factor in the success of agriculture, and may have contributed to the success of sauropods.
